for that data to come down in a in a well-designed app that uses R connect
that data is already there because the synchronization is happening on a background
thread now by the way it's the combination of row connect plus designing it well right you have to
think about taking people in a path through through the app such that you are doing those
synchronizations while they're looking at interesting useful information information so you do have to design it

because it works offline but it will actually appear better and of course the programming model is much easier because
now in your controllers you know Rob was showing you his controllers there your controllers
are not making SQL calls uh or data retrieval calls it's just you know
making omm calls um so beyond that the benefits of R connect is easy backend integration
offline use these are this is a just reminiscent of uh sort of a quick highlighting of some of the bullets that
Mark pointed out um it is more scalable because of the use of the nosql data
it's not because we're smarter it's because we used the reddish database we had second mover Advantage right um if
you look at the other sync servers they all rely upon a relational database and that is the bottleneck if you go in
profile what what it's doing you can you can watch the spikes by process and
you'll see what's doing the work it's that relational database server that's the bottleneck we use redus and it's
screaming fast so those there are I've talked to some of you out there that actually are doing competitive evals
love to see your your own measurements um we'll talk about futures for the next
release our ad hoc anecdotal data is that we're much faster but we are
investing a lot in the next release in doing a very sophisticated
seven-dimensional analysis of analyzing all the various performance parameters it is a
non-trivial effort but it's the way to sort of show definitively yes this is this is definitely a much more scalable
system um we also support things like a metadata framework so we let you handle
changing schemas to backend systems um that's a that's a key challenge that people have is that every company's
system is different if you're an isv you're shipping so if you're a partner that a Motorola partner and you're
shipping to an app to connect to somebody's backend maybe they're all using Salesforce or seil or sap or
whatever and everybody's different how do you handle that variation so we give you a metadata framework that enables
that to be easy to do and it's even helpful in in one in a given company given that their schemas for their back
ends may change um and we support bringing this down to by default
property bags which means that as the schema changes and enhances even without using metadata nothing breaks this has
always been a a a problem and an issue in in U mobile software I need to have
my little iPhone phone prompt so I can always point to that but this has always been an issue um in um mobile software
that unlike uh the web scenario where everything's uh connecting to a central
server in mobile software there's something running here on the edge and it's always been an issue that as things
change on the server it breaks clients and that's true if you have fixed schema if you use a property bag which is what
we enable by default you don't have that issue as new new attributes appear in the server they can just get delivered
to the client in this property bag model which we use by default and of course we
do support fix schemas for other scenarios where property bag may not be
as good like large catalog databases we also support Conflict Management in a very elegant um uh user-driven way
instead of giving you a lot of policies we let you hook in your own Conflict Management validation capability
so this is in more detail the architecture and what I want to highlight uh is a couple things that you
may not be a aware of here the essence of it is in order to make all this magic
happen of getting from the back end down to your device you write a source adapter so that's the essence of it and
those of you that have written um worked with sync servers before that should seem very familiar guess what everybody
calls them Source adapters we didn't invent that term um but there's some other things to to point out to you
first of all we ship with some Source adapters we ship for most of the major popular CRM so um sales for Sugar CRM
Oracle and Microsoft Dynamics we don't ship with every object believe we do
contact leads accounts tasks and opportunities because that's fairly common among the different crms um it's
easy to look at what we ship and and add more objects um and we will do more out
of the box stuff later not as a major theme and here's why we would consider
doing it in partnership with uh we're not app developers and going too far
down the out-of thebox source adapters is we don't want to be there's a lot of motor R Partners here whether you're an
SI or an isv we are your partner we don't want to be removing your value if you're shipping an app that works with
Sugar CRM we have people have done that with rable or Microsoft Dynamics or
seble we want you to make lot millions of dollars selling that app and we never want to stand in the way so we think of
the source adapters as sort of like examples that people can then build upon we would consider adding other source
adapters um but let's take the example of sap we probably wouldn't try to do every object we would do SAP field
service items or time sheets something to sort of show the way and provide a
